review.title: Deontic modality based on preference
review.abstract: Deontic modalities are here defined in terms of the preference relation explored in our previous work (Osherson and Weinstein, 2012). Some consequences of the system are discussed.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: In fact, we have tried to construct a deontic modality based on binary preferences; three systems have been studied; the most basic models of the underlying preference logic, and thus the yields of the least deontic validities [e.g., those shown in Proposition (14); the third system narrows the class of models by identifying worlds with subsets of proposition parameters, and requires selection to minimize the symmetric difference between selected and candidate worlds; new theorems are emerging [see Proposition (19); and the third system imposes an additional restriction on selection by explaining some variables that are more stable than others, leading to further validities [Proposition (23)].At the same time, many implausible deontic principles are ineffective, even in the most constrained third systems.

They encourage a tolerant attitude about alternative systems in the expectation that distinct approaches will prove necessary in different contexts (for example, legal versus technological; see Meyer et al., 1994). It is in this spirit that we here offer a deontic system built upon the preference logic advanced in Osherson and Weinstein (2012). The plan is to define deontic modalities like obligation in terms of the preference relation, then examine the consequences that follow from the underlying preference logic.

Fact (19)a is close to the “contranegativity” principle discussed in Hansson (2002). Hansson’s principle is plausible: If p is obligatory while missing out on q is worse than missing out on p then q should also be obligatory.

Indeed, we hope to have shown that preference-based deontic logic makes tenable distinctions between validity and invalidity, especially when the impact of an obligation is distinguished from the impact of actually fulfilling the obligation [as already noted in Hintikka (1971)].

Rather, we hope to populate the space of credible systems by starting from a novel semantics, namely, the preference semantics elaborated in Osherson and Weinstein (2012). A wide range of deontic logics may prove helpful in analyzing obligation and related concepts, as well as facilitating applications to Decision Science, jurisprudence, etc.
